awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Biobased and Biodegradable Superabsorbent Polymers
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact and commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop a new environmentally sustainable material for diapers and incontinence products. In the US, 25 million adults suffer from urinary incontinence, generating up to 1.5 million kilograms of problematic material for landfills.  The proposed material will be manufactured  using cheap, and renewable raw materials, improving the environmental impact of managing this condition and enabling high quality of life for its users. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project proposes to develop a new superabsorbent polymer (SAP). In the first phase of research, this project will identify design parameters based on polymer architecture, charge density, and gel fraction for a SAP that meets specifications regarding absorbency under load (AUL), centrifuge retention capacity (CRC), and kinetics of absorption. The project will validate the safety and biodegradability in simulated composting conditions. Finally, the project will explore protocols for manufacturing at scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The need for nature-inspired polymeric materials solutions is immensely relevant to society today as we face challenges with depleting petroleum resources and growing concerns about the environmental fate of our consumptions after use. One approach is to make the existing products using renewable raw material resources. Yet, another more rewarding approach is making new polymers inspired by natural raw materials that afford a circular economy.

A serendipitous observation involving the development of esters and amides using naturally available sugar metabolite hydroxy acids inspires our approach. In this project, we demonstrated the synthesis of water-soluble, water-dispersible, and moisture-absorbing polyesters in a chemoselective manner using green chemistry principles. These polymers can then be crosslinked to form hydrogels and superabsorbent polymer gels. We could demonstrate that these hydrogels are non-cytotoxic and safely biodegradable after use. Our goal remains to find the right balance between the time and mode of disassembly for the superabsorbent polymers and their useful life to the consumer, such as those using an incontinence product.

These polyesters derived from sugar metabolites have numerous applications, such as being the hydrophilic head of a polymeric surfactant. Since the polymer synthesis is chemoselective, the polyesters are linear, having a polydispersity index of less than 1.5 and typically in the region of 1.07 to 1.30. We demonstrated their value in cleansing and emulsifying surfactant molecules by coupling the polyester-based hydrophilic head to an alkyl chain sourced naturally from oils.

This project has enabled us to file a patent application covering the matter of composition for a series of condensation polymers. It also enabled us to present our material and data to industry experts. We continue our developmental efforts to bring to market products based on this technology.


Last Modified: 10/11/2023
Modified by: Ananth V Iyer
